description: mingzi
A young adventuress ready to take a break.  \c[4]Garbhan\c[0] and friends sprung her from the jail in \c[4]Toledo\c[0].
One of the last generation's most prominent monster hunters, \c[4]Agamennone\c[0] never yielded an inch in battle.
So named for brutally putting down disorder among nobles.  Fighting against the \c[4]Moors\c[0], led by \c[4]Muhammed IV\c[0].
A brew from the \c[4]Valle dei Setti Morti\c[0].  It has proven very popular, despite limited production.
\c[4]Amalia\c[0] doubles as an adventuress.  Her charm and approachable nature earn her countless fans.
An imposing vessel, the \c[4]Ame Morte\c[0] is an impressive but oddly worn looking \c[4]Galleon\c[0].
Aonghus hails from Scotland.  He uses hand-axes to brutal effect, and lost an eye clearing a \c[4]Gap of Goeblin\c[0].
\c[4]Venice\c[0] is a ship-production power, with some of the world's finest fleet construction facilities - the \c[4]Armoury\c[0].
Said to be part lion, elephant, boar, and bear, all attempts to slay the \c[4]Behemoth\c[0] have failed.
A group of bandits led by an infamous thug named Bosque.  They've terrorized caravans near \c[4]Toledo\c[0] for years.
A witch who once tried to take over England with an army of undead, birthed from her foul magic cauldron.
The soup of \c[4]Branwen\c[0]'s Cauldron can bring the dying back to life, or resurrect the dead as soulless zombies.
A collected 228 poems by three German scribes; \c[4]Peter of Blois\c[0], \c[4]Walter of Chatillon\c[0] and \c[4]Archpoet\c[0].
A maze of tunnels and tombs running underneath \c[4]Paris\c[0] made to hide Christian burials, now unruly with monsters.
A cave running through the thinnest part of the mountains.  Said to be a cursed place where the spirit realm holds dominance.
The act of \c[4]Channeling\c[0].
The process through which humans give mana to spirits and those spirits \c[4]conjure\c[0] up the requested magic in return.
One of the more powerful aristocratic families in \c[4]Paris\c[0], with a long, well-respected lineage.
A French aristocrat prone to lapses of insanity, who once believed he was made of grass.
An evil horse appearing before weary travellers.  Anyone who rode it was never heard from again.
An unknown monster that seems to cause time distortions near itself.
Refers to \c[4]Clement the Fifth\c[0], \c[4]Pope\c[0] from 1305 - 1314.  Responsible for the \c[4]Templar Purge\c[0].
\c[4]Pope\c[0] from 1305 - 1314.  Responsible for the \c[4]Templar Purge\c[0].  Moved the \c[4]Curia\c[0] to \c[4]Avignon\c[0].
An old clock tower towering over \c[4]St. Mark's Square\c[0], it would later be torn down.
Near the southern tip of South Africa.  Many ships have fallen prey to fierce storms in the region.
The act of \c[4]Conjuring\c[0].
The process through which spirits create and manipulate the elements, usually in response to \c[4]Channeling\c[0].
There are a surprising number of tales of cursed rings, but what happens if the curse is broken?
A fire-breathing \c[4]Wyrm\c[0]-like creature, noted for its habit of hoarding food and treasures.
A blacksmith in \c[4]Venice\c[0]'s \c[4]Armoury\c[0] district, near the \c[4]Monster Hunters Guild\c[0].
\c[4]Davy Jones\c[0] is a devil to sailors, one who drags them down to his locker - his troves at the bottom of the sea.
The \c[4]De La Fleurs\c[0] are new to wealth.  Their fame saw them rise from travelling bard to upper class.
The process where priests forcibly expel a demon possessing someone or something.  Vital to resist the darkness.
A foul creature that feasts upon corpses.  Special care must be taken to bury the dead properly to avoid drawing its attention.
The chief magistrate of \c[4]Venice\c[0], essentially its ruler or king.
A Eurocentric term for East Asia; China, Japan, the Philippines, and so on.
Impressive large warships, especially popular in Spain.  Built with multiple decks and masts.
A huge serpent drenched red in the gore of countless men and beasts.  The fiend can regenerate itself, but fears fire.
So-named for convenience, the Germanic region didn't unify into the country \c[4]Germany\c[0] until 1871.
The 51st \c[4]Doge\c[0] of \c[4]Venice\c[0], he ascended to the role on July 13, 1312.
The realm of the dead, in which Death rules undisputed.  Widespread, and split into numerous geographic zones.
The manifestion of death, a \c[4]Grim Reaper\c[0] reaps souls like farmers reap wheat, scythe and all.
A festival centering around the \c[4]Tarasque\c[0], in which hidden desires are brought out into the open for a night.
A hall in every \c[4]Monster Hunter Guild\c[0] branch dedicated to the remembrance of great and deceased members.
An oddly notorious assassin, who makes a game out of his hunt.  Talented enough to succeed despite the public eye on him.
A title of respect for the \c[4]Pope\c[0] and other high-ranking members of the Clergy.
Annual festival started in 1315 by \c[4]Doge\c[0] \c[4]Giovanni Soranzo\c[0], comprising a parade and rowing boat races.
The \c[4]Holy Catholic Church\c[0], the heart of which is the \c[4]Vatican\c[0].
An honorific term for Israel, particularly Jerusalem, which is claimed by all big three monotheistic religions.
The name of a hermit blacksmith in \c[4]Venice\c[0], renouned for his impressive quality of work.
A male demon said to pray on sleeping women.  The female equivalent of a \c[4]Succubus\c[0].
A relic specifically enchanted to protect the wearer from magical \c[4]Sleep\c[0] attacks.
Highly talented wandering entertainers skilled in dancing, acrobatics, and juggling.
Highly talented wandering entertainers skilled in dancing, acrobatics, and juggling.
Reputedly the earliest French play, written in roughly 1282 by \c[4]Adam de la Halle\c[0].
\c[4]Louis the Stubborn\c[0] fights with the nobility.  He abolished slavery in France.
A large Catholic military order, wealthy and powerful.  Very highly skilled.  Fought prominently in the \c[4]Crusades\c[0].
Flesh-eating fairies that entrap victims in very convincing illusions.
The vengeful spirit of a young mother driven insane with grief after drowning her own children.
A greater death spirit, made manifest as a giant mish-mash of corpses.  Each of the corpses has an unlife of its own.
A great serpentine dragon.  It rules the waters undisputed, and is responsible for the ruin of countless ships.
A realm where the dead wait for judgement, which will either send them to heaven or hell.
A common light alcohol for young adults, given to them before coming of age ceremonies or on other special occassions.
\c[4]King Louis X\c[0] doesn't see eye-to-eye with most nobles.  He abolished slavery in France.
A well-regarded Parisian Vineyard started by a young couple with a deep love for wine.
Man-eating living plants. Pheromones used to draw creatures near, and tendrils draw victims into their many mouths.
\c[4]Tartans\c[0] are green and blue. Their emblem is a lone tower, and their motto is '\c[4]In ardua tendit\c[0].'
A former \c[4]Templar\c[0], \c[4]Marduk\c[0] proved impressive in many battles.  Retired after the \c[4]Templar Purge\c[0].
A high-ranking \c[4]Templar\c[0] charged with territory, recruiting, and supervision of \c[4]officers\c[0].
Powerful and talented individuals specialized in killing monsters.  Often somewhat mentally unstable.
Powerful and talented individuals specialized in killing monsters.  Often somewhat mentally unstable.
A number of \c[4]Chapters\c[0] spread across Europe working as a recently unified guild for \c[4]Monster Hunters\c[0].
A number of \c[4]Chapters\c[0] spread across Europe working as a recently unified guild for \c[4]Monster Hunters\c[0].
A dark, thick ale.  It's quite strong, and smells of mud and pine, hence the name.
Not much is known about this beer.
A terrible demon resembling a man shorn vertically, but is decidedly deadly, and faster than any would expect it to be.
A gothic cathedral whose treasury contains the \c[4]Crown of Thorns\c[0] and a fragment of the \c[4]True Cross\c[0].
One of many small parks arrayed around \c[4]Notre Dame Cathedral\c[0] and the waterways passing around it.
A monastery past its glory years, frequently a point of shelter for caravans tracking between \c[4]Toledo\c[0] and \c[4]Paris\c[0].
Any of twelve peers of \c[4]Charlemagne's court\c[0].  The term since distinguishes knights for heroism and chivalry.
More than one \c[4]Paladin\c[0].  The term has since come to refer to '\c[4]Holy knights\c[0].'
The capital of \c[4]France\c[0], seat of the King of France and one of the largest cities in all of Europe.
The \c[4]Watch\c[0] or guards responsible for keeping order in \c[4]Paris\c[0].
A beast tough enough to survive the \c[4]Great Flood\c[0].  A foul creature that causes wilts crops and causes famine.
The \c[4]Bishop\c[0] of \c[4]Rome\c[0], head of the \c[4]Roman Catholic Church\c[0].
An aspect of death, a spirit that consumes the lives of the living almost without effort.
More than one \c[4]Reaper\c[0].  A complete and literal death sentence.
One of \c[4]Castille's\c[0] more powerful \c[4]guilds\c[0], unifying many smaller mining merchants.
An exceptional woman, favoring heavy armor, nicknamed the \c[4]Rook\c[0] after defending a flank single-handedly.
Creatures of the deep, encircling \c[4]R'lyeh\c[0].  They come to the surface to sow chaos and discord.
A \c[4]Grim Reaper\c[0], reported as a procession of ghostly white figures.  It can kill simply by making eye contact!
Roughly half of \c[4]Scotland\c[0], tending West and North.  A mountainous area.
A potent lime-tinted mead.  Named after a group of frogs were found sloshed by a cracked keg of the stuff.
A beautiful trail winding along the coast, frequented for trade.  Sadly, the area has a long history of bandit problems.
The most famous cathedral church in \c[4]Venice\c[0]; originally, the chapel of the \c[4]Doge\c[0].
A picturesque square in \c[4]Venice\c[0], featuring the \c[4]Clocktower\c[0], \Basilica\c[0] and \c[4]Doge\c[0]'s Offices.
A poisonous harpy creature, without pupils.  This fiend feds on human flesh and blood, Particularly that of infants.
Part-demon, part-human, transform shortly after coming of age.  Sustains herself by draining lifeforce of bed mates.
Offspring of the \c[4]Onachus\c[0] and \c[4]Leviathan\c[0], a dark beast that draws out evil hidden in men's hearts.
A large-scale \c[4]Witch-hunt\c[0] resulting in imprisonment, exile, or execution for many \c[4]Templars\c[0].
A large Catholic military order, wealthy and powerful.  Very highly skilled.  Fought prominently in the \c[4]Crusades\c[0].
A Scottish berserker, bearing light armor and a two-handed axe.  His wild slashes create crimson sprays in battle.
Reaching an incredible 8 feet in height, Tearlaidh towered over his opponents.  Died gloriously slaying \c[4]Amphisbaena\c[0].
An old city, with a long history of co-existence between \c[4]Christians\c[0], \c[4]Muslims\c[0], and \c[4]Jews\c[0].  Famous for \c[4]Toledo Steel\c[0].
The \c[4]Watch\c[0] or guards responsible for keeping order in \c[4]Toledo\c[0].
A prized metal alloy first used by \c[4]Hannibal\c[0] and his armies.  Bends instead of snapping in half when put under great strain.
The ghosts of miners killed in cave-ins, tied to this world by regrets.  Disposition ranges from mischievious to malevolent.
The ghosts of miners killed in cave-ins, tied to this world by regrets.  Disposition ranges from mischievious to malevolent.
A small European country near Romania under the rule of the bloodthirsty \c[4]Vlad the Impaler\c[0].
A small but popular brewery based in the \c[4]Valle dei Setti Morti\c[0].
A large marsh whose name means 'Valley of the Seven Dead,' after tales about undead slaughtering a large family.
\c[4]Vatican City\c[0], a small city-state within \c[4]Rome\c[0] ruled by the \c[4]Pope\c[0].  Most famous for \c[4]St. Peter's Basilica\c[0].
A bustling port-city located in \c[4]Venetian Lagoon\c[0], across 117 small islands interwoven by canals and bridges.
One living in \c[4]Venice\c[0].
The \c[4]Watch\c[0] or guards responsible for keeping order in \c[4]Venice\c[0].
A lively pub popular with artisans and civilians, located on the eastern side of \c[4]Venice\c[0].
Spirits of those who died in the swamps, notorious for either leading travelers to great fortune or to certain death.
One of many isolated towns rumoured to have disappeared overnight, perhaps the victim of war or monsters.
